head.title: Three Are Treated After Witnessing Suicide

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York
Top/News/Health/Diseases, Conditions, and Health Topics/Suicides and Suicide Attempts

hedline.hl1: Three Are Treated After Witnessing Suicide

abstract.p: Three people are treated for trauma after man jumps to his death from 17th floor of midtown Manhattan building as they were leaving subway station (S)

block.p: Three people were treated for trauma yesterday after a man jumped to his death from the 17th floor of a midtown Manhattan building as they were leaving a subway station, the police said.

The man jumped from the McAlpin House at 50 West 34th Street on the corner of the Avenue of the Americas at 8:30 A.M.. Eyewitnesses said one of the three people who saw the suicide, a 10-year-old boy, was struck by the man's leg, which had detached from his body following the initial impact from the fall.
Three people were treated for trauma yesterday after a man jumped to his death from the 17th floor of a midtown Manhattan building as they were leaving a subway station, the police said.

The man jumped from the McAlpin House at 50 West 34th Street on the corner of the Avenue of the Americas at 8:30 A.M.. Eyewitnesses said one of the three people who saw the suicide, a 10-year-old boy, was struck by the man's leg, which had detached from his body following the initial impact from the fall.

That boy, his 7-year-old brother and their 34-year-old mother were all taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where they were treated for trauma and received counseling before they were released, said Lorinda Klein, a Bellevue spokeswoman.
The man, Joel Levine, 42, an accountant who had an office in the building, also crashed through a newsstand on the sidewalk.
